statement.tex: %text A family has 2 children. Find the probability that both are boys, if it is known that (i) at least one of the children is a boy, (ii) the elder child is a boy. %

step.context: %text Given the following variables % \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|} \hline N_B & C_1 & C_2 \\ \hline \text{Number of boys} & \text{First child} & \text{Second child}\\ \hline \end{tabular}\\ \underline\text{what probabilities are we supposed to find?}
step.reason:
%text When you have to find the probability of event A happening \underline\text{given that} event B has already occurred, then you must start thinking of \underline\text{conditional probability} $P(A\vert B)$.
And so, if we were to define the following
% \begin{tabular}{|c|c|} \hline \text{Event} & \text{Meaning} \\ \hline N_B = 2 & \text{Both boys} \\ \hline N_B\geq 1 &\text{At least one boy} \\ \hline C_1 = boy & \text{First child is a boy}\\ \hline \end{tabular}\\ %text
then it is clear that we have to find the following \underline\text{conditional probabilities}.
% \begin{tabular}{|c|c|} \hline \text{Probability} & \text{Meaning} \\ \hline P(N_B = 2\,\vert\,N_B\geq 1) & \text{Both boys given}\\ &\text{atleast one boy} \\ \hline P(N_B = 2\,\vert\,C_1=boy) & \text{Both boys given} \\ &\text{first child is a boy} \\ \hline \end{tabular}
